A basic_face_identification is a type of that identifies a face of a solid shape. The identified face has either been created by a construction operation, or is part of an imported model to be used as a basis for construction operations. The attribute containing_model represents a solid shape containing the face.
Most of construction operations are defined in the solid_shape_element_schema of ISO 10303-111, some operations are defined in the geometric_model_schema of ISO 10303-42.
The attribute containing_model will be redefined, or constrained, in the subtypes of this entity, to restrict the value to appropriate subtypes relating to construction operations defined in ISO 10303-42 or ISO 10303-111.

An imported_face_identification is a type of that specifies a face in an imported B-rep model. The imported_face_identification has attributes which directly reference an instance of and an instance of a which contains that surface.
Typical design process often starts from an existing B-rep model that has no construction history. Users import the existing B-rep model and start modelling using CAD systems. Therefore, it is required to identify shape elements such as faces, edges, and vertices in the imported B-rep model to apply further construction operations to the solid.
If it is required to identify a particular edge or vertex of an imported B-rep model this can be done by using the entities or from this part of ISO 10303 together with appropriate instances of imported_face_identification to identify the adjacent faces.

A profile_based_feature_identification is a type of that specifies a face relating to a profile based feature.
A solid created from profile based feature has at most one initial and one terminal face. Lateral faces can be related to a particular edge of the profile. Therefore, the attribute face_creation_type is sufficient to identify an initial or a terminal face. The other attribute edge_segment has a null value for initial and terminal faces, but is required for lateral face identification.
The profile based features can be classified into additive and subtractive features in terms of the difference between the volume of the original solid and that of the resulting solid. This entity is intended for the identification of both additive and subtractive profile based features.

ext_description.p: An ambiguity_resolution is a type of that specifies the information needed to resolve the ambiguity between the topological entities having the same basic identification in the old model (pre-edit model) and new model (post-edit model). There are two types of ambiguity to be resolved, one is when faces are split, and the other is when faces are merged.

A split_element_information is a type of that specifies the SEI to resolve the ambiguity when element split occurs. The SEIs of split elements are determined by calculating x, y, and z values of reference points on the split elements in the object space and then assigning priorities, or element_order to the split elements. The object space is the local 3D Cartesian coordinate space of the form feature.

For the calculation of SEIs, it is required to determine reference points of the topological entities having the same identifications. Reference points of two topological entities that may cause ambiguity shall be different.
ext_description.note: A possible algorithm for determining reference points is described below [4]. Suppose A and B are split faces as illustrated in Figure 18. Firstly, axis-aligned bounding boxes for A, B are generated. Then, all the boundary lines of the smaller bounding box are extended. If there is no intersection between extended lines and the other face, any points in A and B can be selected as illustrated in Figure 18 (a). If there is an intersection between the extended lines of A and face B, one of the intersecting points should be selected as illustrated in Figure 18 (b). If there are intersections in many directions, extended lines parallel to x axis have the first priority, and extended lines parallel to y axis have the second priority, and extended lines parallel to z axis have the last priority. If there are multiple intersections in one direction, all the intersecting points will be compared by their coordinates. For the comparison of coordinates, x precedes y and y precedes z, and a point with the smallest value will be selected.

A topology_based_element_identification is a type of that specifies the identifications of topological elements such as face, edge, and vertex.

A topology_based_face_identification is a type of that represents the identification of a face entity based on its topological information. A face can be created by a construction operation, and can also be split or merged during the design process. Therefore, the face can be identified by its face_basic_identification together with, if needed, face_SEI and face_MEI.
the basic identification of the given face;
the split element information of the face;
the merged element information of the face.

A topology_based_edge_identification is a type of that represents the identification of an edge entity based on its topological information. An edge can be identified by of two adjacent faces and, if required, edge_SEI.
In Figure 21, edge 1 and edge 2 have the same two adjacent faces. Therefore, the use of an appropriate reference point is required to identify the particular edge as a split element information.
A case for split element information of edges
the identification of the adjacent face to the left of the edge;
the identification of the adjacent face to the right of the edge;
the split element information of the edge.

A topology_based_vertex_identification is a type of that represents the identification of a vertex entity based on its topological information. A vertex can be identified by the list of of adjacent faces and, if required, vertex_SEI.
In Figure 22, vertex 1 and vertex 2 have the same adjacent faces which are face 1, face 2, and face 3. Therefore, the use of an appropriate reference point is required to identify the particular vertex as a split element information. In this case, x, y, and z coordinates of a vertex become a reference point.
In general cases, a vertex has three or more adjacent faces. In case of a cone, however, the apex of a cone has just one adjacent face. Therefore, the minimum number of adjacent_faces becomes one.

A user_selected_topology_element is a type of and represents an element selected via its persistent identification in the procedural shape model.
A user_selected_topology_element instance can be used as an element in a set of instances defined in the attribute of the entity defined in ISO 10303-55 [2].
This entity user_selected_topology_element selects an element which is topologically identified by mechanisms defined in this part of ISO 10303, whereas selects an element geometrically from the users view point. If a model is procedurally created from scratch by construction operations, all the elements comprising the model can be therefore topologically identified, user_selected_topology_element can be substituted for for selecting an element. In other words, both entities can be used interchangeably to identify a selected element.
the unique identification of the topological entity which is being selected.

The boolean function face_in_brep accepts as input a and a and returns TRUE if the face is one of the faces used to define the shells of the B-rep. The function first uses the function to construct the set of all the shells of the B-rep. For each of this set it uses the function to construct a list of faces, each face in the list is compared to the input test_face and, if identical the function returns TRUE. If no match is found after all faces of all shells have been tested the function returns FALSE.
The functions and are defined in ISO 10303-42.
